results.title: Cancer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Discusses the nature of cancer cells, and how they are identified. Stresses the importance of early diagnosis and prompt treatment in the cure of many cases. Shows the method of self-examination of the breasts; emphasises the need for women to have regular cell tests for uterine cancer; and the value of regular chest X-rays. Shows the work done by the Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria, the Cytology Service at Prince Henry’s Hospital and the Peter MacCallum Clinic.

results.title: Canberra today and tomorrow
results.brief_description: The rapidly developing capital city of Australia. Its beautiful site and many parks and gardens; national traditions enshrined in the Australian War Memorial, the Royal Military College of Duntroon and in Parliament House. The diplomatic missions, Canberra University College, research institutions. The corporate life of the city and plans for its future.
results.description: The rapidly developing capital city of Australia. results.title: Canaries to clydesdales
results.creator_credit: Eugene Boyko, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A view of the practice of veterinary partners working in the Okanagan Valley of British Columbia. Thirty thousand miles of house calls a year is routine for these two country veterinarians whose patients include just about any creature that hops, trots, swims or flies. This film follows Doctors Vic Demetrick and Reg Maidment through the daily rounds that take them from sterile clinic to farm paddock. The devoted vets obviously relish their work. They display an enormous warmth and respect for each other, their animal patients, and their human clients. “Canaries to Clydesdales” shows that it takes compassion, commitment, and a strong dose of humour to succeed in this profession. After seeing this veterinary team at work, the career-minded will have the personal insight to evaluate their own qualifications. Awards: New York; Birmingham

results.title: Canadian wheat story
results.creator_credit: Beth Zinkan, Gudrun Parker, Bill MacDonald and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is the story of what happens to the great wheat crops of western Canada after the harvest. The route is traced from the farm to the town elevator, by box car to the huge concrete storage cylinders at terminal points on the Great Lakes, down the Lakes to the homes and bakeries of eastern Canada, and to the ocean ports for shipment abroad.

results.title: Canadian profile
results.creator_credit: Allan Wargon, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An informal portrait of the people of Canada at a time when modern technology is reaching into every phase of national life. Beginning with the fishermen of Newfoundland and ending with the Kitimat project on the west coast, the film explores the demands of a new machine age on people of diverse origins in whom the feeling for tradition is strong. In all there is evidence of change, adjustment, adaption as the industrial expansion becomes increasingly accelerated. Award: Toronto

results.title: Canadian landscape
results.creator_credit: F.R. Crawley, Ottawa Film Unit and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A study of the characteristic style of A.Y. Jackson, one of Canada’s foremost modern painters. Jackson learned to select the more characteristic forms in his subject and underline their dominant tones and shapes. He first made small sketches on wooden panels which formed a basis for the larger compositions on canvas which were executed later in the studio. The film accurately describes the scenes of rural Quebec in winter and spring, and of northern Ontario in summer and autumn.
results.creator_credit_for_label: F.R. Crawley, Ottawa Film Unit and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Canadian geography. No. 1. Physical regions of Canada
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A study of the physical and economic geography of Canada on the basis of six natural divisions: the Pacific Coast region, the Great Plains, the Laurentian Shield, the St. Lawrence Lowlands, the Atlantic region and the Arctic Islands. In each region the film interprets the relationship of topography, climate and natural resources to the industries or occupations of its inhabitants.

results.title: Canada: Toronto and Niagara Falls
results.creator_credit: Carmen Bourquardez and Hughes Leisure Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Travel, Travel”.
Visits the museums, malls and churches of Toronto and features what to see as a tourist in this city which mixes the old with the new. A religious group the Mennonites, are encountered and later at Toronto’s own Oktoberfest, we join in with the celebration. Journeying to Stratford, we go backstage at the Festival Theatre. The spectacular Niagara Falls and some of the neighbouring attractions are also visited on this journey.

results.title: Canada: landform regions
results.creator_credit: Eugene Boyko, Frank Spiller, Sidney Goldsmith and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A view of Canada from a helicopter, showing the nature and extent of the various landform regions. We see the immense spread of forest, rock and lakeland that makes up the Canadian Shield, the plains and lowlands where the industry of man is more evident, and finally, the coastal mountain ranges of the west, north and east. The influence of the geological character of the land on what people do and where they live is illustrated in closer views of industry, urban and rural, across the country. Photography: Eugene Boyko. Award: Sydney
